You may be interested in his early life under Chinazi:
https://web.archive.org/web/20160403190411/http://simplysharing.com/assuringlight/solomonyue.htm

"Whether it’s his house, his two businesses or his political views, Yue has lived in America with a single-minded goal: “To turn Karl Marx over in his grave.”

Yue, 47, was only 7 when China’s Cultural Revolution started, but his voice grows tight with anger when he recalls the day the Communists forced his parents to give up two rooms of their Shanghai house for poor families.

(His grandfather) John Yue escaped to Hong Kong in 1949, but the government punished his descendants in Shanghai because he was active in the Methodist Church and owned his own tailoring business.

More specifically, young Solomon made a habit of resisting the daily lessons of Mao’s Little Red Book and Karl Marx’s Communist Manifesto. He argued with teachers, pointing out the flaws of communism. They, in turn, made him write “self-criticism” and sent him to a farm for re-education, where he says he was forced to spread cow dung on rice fields with his bare hands."

Finally we see someone taking his revenge towards CCP, in the name of the millions suffering from Chinazi. Salute to Mr. Yue, and God bless Hong Kong.

You may be interested in his early life under Chinazi:
https://web.archive.org/web/20160403190411/http://simplysharing.com/assuringlight/solomonyue.htm

"Whether it’s his house, his two businesses or his political views, Yue has lived in America with a single-minded goal: “To turn Karl Marx over in his grave.”

Yue, 47, was only 7 when China’s Cultural Revolution started, but his voice grows tight with anger when he recalls the day the Communists forced his parents to give up two rooms of their Shanghai house for poor families.

(His grandfather) John Yue escaped to Hong Kong in 1949, but the government punished his descendants in Shanghai because he was active in the Methodist Church and owned his own tailoring business.

More specifically, young Solomon made a habit of resisting the daily lessons of Mao’s Little Red Book and Karl Marx’s Communist Manifesto. He argued with teachers, pointing out the flaws of communism. They, in turn, made him write “self-criticism” and sent him to a farm for re-education, where he says he was forced to spread cow dung on rice fields with his bare hands."

Finally we see someone taking his revenge towards CCP, in the name of the millions suffering from Chinazi. Salute to Mr. Yue, and God bless Hong Kong.

"Whether it’s his house, his two businesses or his political views, Yue has lived in America with a single-minded goal: “To turn Karl Marx over in his grave.”

Yue, 47, was only 7 when China’s Cultural Revolution started, but his voice grows tight with anger when he recalls the day the Communists forced his parents to give up two rooms of their Shanghai house for poor families.

(His grandfather) John Yue escaped to Hong Kong in 1949, but the government punished his descendants in Shanghai because he was active in the Methodist Church and owned his own tailoring business.

More specifically, young Solomon made a habit of resisting the daily lessons of Mao’s Little Red Book and Karl Marx’s Communist Manifesto. He argued with teachers, pointing out the flaws of communism. They, in turn, made him write “self-criticism” and sent him to a farm for re-education, where he says he was forced to spread cow dung on rice fields with his bare hands."

Yue, 47, was only 7 when China’s Cultural Revolution started, but his voice grows tight with anger when he recalls the day the Communists forced his parents to give up two rooms of their Shanghai house for poor families.

(His grandfather) John Yue escaped to Hong Kong in 1949, but the government punished his descendants in Shanghai because he was active in the Methodist Church and owned his own tailoring business.

More specifically, young Solomon made a habit of resisting the daily lessons of Mao’s Little Red Book and Karl Marx’s Communist Manifesto. He argued with teachers, pointing out the flaws of communism. They, in turn, made him write “self-criticism” and sent him to a farm for re-education, where he says he was forced to spread cow dung on rice fields with his bare hands."
